thread.title_full: Zealand Pharma Falls Short of FDA Approval for Glepaglutide | Morningstar

title: Zealand Pharma Falls Short of FDA Approval for Glepaglutide | Morningstar
text:
Zealand Pharma Falls Short of FDA Approval for Glepaglutide
By Stephen Nakrosis
Zealand Pharma said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration concluded that the company's new drug application for proposed short bowel syndrome treatment glepaglutide didn't meet full requirements, adding it will continue dialogue with the agency.
The FDA, in a complete response letter pertaining to the NDA, said the application didn't meet full requirements for substantial evidence to establish the efficacy and safety of the treatment's to-be-marketed dose, said Zealand.
David Kendall, the Denmark-based biotech company's chief medical officer, said Zealand was disappointed in the FDA's decision and remains confident the data showed robust and compelling evidence of glepaglutide's efficacy and safety.
Zealand said it would continue working with the FDA on a path toward obtaining regulatory approval in the U.S.
Zealand also said it expects to proceed with plans for a European Marketing Authorization Application submission next year.
Write to Stephen Nakrosis at stephen.nakrosis@wsj.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires
December 19, 2024 16:10 ET (21:10 GMT)
